intro: Lycianthes umbonata, commonly known as the Mexican groundcherry, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its small, egg-shaped fruits that turn orange when ripe. The plant typically grows as an annual or biennial herb with hairy stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers are yellow with purple veins, and it produces a mild, tangy flavor in its edible fruits. Lycianthes umbonata is often cultivated for both ornamental and culinary purposes.
